title: Hawkenbury, Tunbridge Wells
text:
Hawkenbury is a small village area located in the south east of <a href="Royal%20Tunbridge%20Wells">Royal Tunbridge Wells</a>, <a href="Kent">Kent</a>, England.
History.
Hawkenbury was settled before Tunbridge Wells itself was founded in the 17th century, and at one time fell within the <a href="civil%20parish">parish</a> of <a href="Frant">Frant</a>, lying as it then did in <a href="Sussex">Sussex</a>. It was originally known as "Hockenbury".
Bacon's 1912 map of Tunbridge Wells shows the centre of Hawkenbury lying along Hawkenbury Road, being that area currently lying south of the recreation ground. The Victorian estate around Sibby's Corner was not then considered part of Hawkenbury. Hawkenbury had no less than four places of worship, being a <a href="Congregationalist">Congregationalist</a> chapel (now <a href="United%20Reformed%20Church">United Reformed Church</a>) at Sibby's Corner, a St. Peter's Mission on the junction of Forest Road and Napier Road, an unnamed church on Hawkenbury Road (below the present site of Hawkenbury Mews) and a second Congregationalist chapel lay below the present site of the Hawkenbury Road allotments, as did a number of village dwellings. Beyond agriculture, the residents were employed in the Brickfields, lying due east of present-day Maryland Road. South of Brickfields were a plethora of now-vanished farm buildings, the remains of which can still be traced from the footpath off Chieveley Drive. In 1912 Halls Hole Road was called Marlpits Lane and Whybourne Gate Farm lay on the site of the current Whybourne Crest.
Governance.
Hawkenbury is located within the <a href="Park%20%28Tunbridge%20Wells%29">Park</a> <a href="Wards%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">ward</a> of Tunbridge Wells, and elects three councillors to Tunbridge Wells Borough Council. Hawkenbury is not part of a <a href="Parish%20councils%20in%20England">parish council</a> (the Borough Council acts as the Parish). Hawkenbury falls under the Tunbridge Wells South district at <a href="Kent%20County%20Council">county</a> level. Hawkenbury is part of the constituency of <a href="Tunbridge%20Wells%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Tunbridge Wells</a> at a <a href="Parliament%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">national level</a>. Prior to <a href="Brexit">Brexit</a> in 2020, it was represented by the <a href="South%20East%20England%20%28European%20Parliament%20constituency%29">South East England constituency</a> for the <a href="European%20Union">European Union parliament</a>.
Transport.
The closest railway station is <a href="Tunbridge%20Wells%20railway%20station">Tunbridge Wells</a>. Buses serve Hawkenbury from Monday to Saturday, and are provided by Nu-Venture.
Parks and open spaces.
Farmcombe Road Open Space is a small open green area. Camden Park contains a pastoral area, known as The Meadow, in the middle of an estate developed by <a href="Marquess%20Camden">Lord Camden</a> in the mid-19th century. The Hawkenbury Recreation Ground is a large public space that has <a href="cricket%20pitch">cricket</a> and <a href="Association%20football%20pitch">football</a> pitches, <a href="tennis%20court">tennis court</a>s, an <a href="artificial%20turf">all-weather pitch</a> and a children's play area.
There are also <a href="allotment%20%28gardening%29">allotments</a> in Hawkenbury, in Halls Hole Road, managed by the Hawkenbury Allotment Holders' Association.
